column2: Cheaper than a speeding Greyhound? Convenient as a limousine? A combination of low cost and flexibility? That's drive-away.
INTEREST in physical fitness and exercise has been growing nationally, but nowhere with greater en thusiasm than in the suburbs, where it's difficult to find a truly sedentary being.

Three brothers from Argentina have been convicted in Federal court in Manhattan on charges of conspiracy, racketeering and harboring illegal aliens who worked as prostitutes at the Pleasure Seekers Club at 300 West 45th Street.

Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the New York State Assembly, said yesterday in Brooklyn that the state would assume full fiscal responsibility over the City University of New York in the "foreseeable future."

Cantor David Osen of the Jewish Community Center of Teaneck, N.J., and Mrs. Osen of Teaneck, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Beverly Osen, to Alan Rosmarin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Rosmarin of Edison, N.J.

THE aromas that fill the halls of the International Students Dormitory at dinnertime here indicate more than the simultaneous preparation of Indian curried rice, Chinese chow mein and Iranian kebabs. They reflect the presence of numerous ethnic enclaves, each with its own characteristics, and combine to make the campus a kind of academic United Nations.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--Small towns have won a victory with publication of new Federal regulations broadening their eligibility for community development aid.

WASHINGTON--Twenty-five years ago today, the death of Stalin was announced in Moscow. I asked a recent Soviet visitor whether the event would be observed in his country. He said perhaps only in Soviet Georgia where Stalin still occupied a special place.
At 9:50 on the blustery night of March 5, 1953--or so the official communique stated--Josef V. Stalin died of a massive brain hemorrhage.
As a vision of America, "Images of Kin" could have been the epilogue to Hart Crane's masterpiece, "The Bridge"--were Crane alive today to see the country in less-than-glorious light.

OH, TO BE out of the heavy woolly layers of winter clothes and into the lightweight ma terials of spring, the cool cottons, soft silks and airy knits. Off with the boots and heavy stockings. On with the sandals and sheer pantyhose (or none at all).

ROME, March 4--The Christian Democratic Prime Minister-designate, Giulio Andreotti, met today with leaders of the Communist Party and four smaller parties amid signs of a compromise to resolve Italy's government crisis. Negotiations are expected to continue through next week and perhaps longer.

Sylvia Palacios Whitman is a conjurer. If her conjures were sometimes a little clumsily executed in a concert on Friday at the Truck and Warehouse Theater, she was nevertheless able to summon up images of simple visual beauty and even the potent evocative content of a dream image remembered suddenly, long after waking.
NEW HAVEN "What are you looking for?" a woman shopper called to a man sweeping a strange device back and forth over a small area between sidewalk and curb in downtown New Haven.

Are today's college students sufficiently literate in world affairs? How does one educate a foreign "area specialist?" Why are more and more countries in the Middle East closing their doors to American scholars--and what can the Government do about it? These are some of the questions to be taken up by a new Presidential Commission on Foreign Language and International Studies.
Lingerie used to be fashion's top-secret undercover story. Gloriously embellished corsets and frilly underpinnings made their impressions behind closed doors and beneath buttoned dresses.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 4 (UPI)-- Sly Williams scored 19 points and Stan Wright had 17 today, to lead Rhode Island to a 65-62 victory over Providence in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Divison I New England tournament. The Rams, 24-6, receive an automatic berth in the National Collegiate post-season tournament, and Providence, 24-7, could be invited to fill an at-large berth.

Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Paul Herrington Jr. of Greensburg, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Byers Herrington, to Eli Whitney Debevoise 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Debevoise 2d of Woodstock, Vt. A wedding in July is planned.

FOR years, Boston's Cafe, one of the oldest restaurants in Trenton, was famous for keeping people out. Johnny Boston and his wife ran the place as a family affair and banished whomever they wanted, including notables like Richard J. Hughes, once Governor and now chief justice of the State Supreme Court, provosts of Princeton University and well-known writers like John McPhee.

Melinda Lou Cannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thurlow Orr Cannon of Canton, N.Y., was married yesterday in St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church in Hempstead, L.I., to Richard Carey Alcott, son of Dorothy Ennis Alcott of Valley Stream, L.I., and Dr. William Bruce Alcott of West Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Nicholas Magoulias performed the ceremony.

A front end loader bit into a huge pile of plaster and wood. Wires and pipes lay tangled. Dust hung over the rubblestrewn site. You might have thought the place had been bombed or swept by a tornado, except for the satisfied expression on the face of Richard Stern.
AFTER a period of relatively good feelings, it appears that many Long Islanders are returning to one of their favorite pastimes--picking on the Long Island Rail Road.

City College scored four times in the last 15 minutes, twice in short-handed situations, and beat Queens College, 5-3, to win the City University of New York hockey championship Friday night at the Westchester Ice Skating Rink.

IT has irregularly occurred to me that the urge, to self-destruct is grounded in the deep-seated belief that circumstances are ultimately going to get the better of us, no matter what we do, so we might as well accelerate the process and get the whole thing over with.

In reporting the findings of a recent study indicating that an existing drug, Anturane, can reduce sudden deaths from heart attacks in patients who have had a previous attack, the New England Journal of Medicine has raised hopes of a new weapon against the nation's leading killer. But the study also resurrects some old questions over the use of human subjects in medical research.

Queens College advanced to the semifinals of the Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women's Region 1A playoffs tonight with a 95-62 victory over Boston University at Queens's FitzGerald Gym.

TO help Long Islanders with the difficult task of finding and purchasing the best hospital care, Community Advocates has pre pared a guide showing casts, what is available, where it is and how to get there.
Mr. and Mrs. David Guild Dethlefs of Dedham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Swaim Dethlefs, to Wallace Carne Schling of Dover, Mass., a bulding contractor.
WHERE have all the miniskirts gone? Right to the tennis courts where, along with tank tops and camisoles they are part of the boom in separates for active sports.

Mr. and Mrs. Crystal Lang of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Joan Lang, to Brian Ruder, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ruder of Harrison, N.Y. The couple, 1976 graduates of Washington University in St. Louis, will be married June 25.

LAUREL, Miss., March 4 (AP)--A bus carrying a junior college choir plunged down a 12-foot ravine today near here, injuring at least 34 persons, the authorities said. Most of the injuries were minor, but one passenger underwent surgery, a spokesman for the Jones County Community Hospital in Laurel said.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 4 (AP)-- William L. McKnight, who went to work in 1907 as a bookkeeper making $11.50 a week and became chairman of the board of the 3M Company, died today at his home here. He was 90 years old.

There are no yodeling mountaineers, no cuckoo clocks and almost no Alps in Switzerland. Or so we might suppose after looking at the exhibition, "Passport to the World: Swiss Photographers From 1840 Until Today," at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, through March 16.

HARTFORD, March 4--Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. took "junk journalism" to task tonight in defending the accomplishments of the Carter Administration and, apparently, himself against the press, before a gathering of Democrats here.

HYDE PARK AS a student, Matthew Wolf may pinch pennies with the best of them, but he never worries about his next meal. Despite a limited budget, he lunches in dining rooms resplendent with chandeliers that offer such fare as pate en croute, smoked capon, chateaubriand and delicate, fine French pastries.

Patricia Cronin Buck, daughter of Mrs. Thomas F. Buck of Montrose, Pa., and the late Mr. Buck, was married yesterday afternoon to David DeVeau Sleeper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon C. Sleeper Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y.

Longstanding rumors that there was little in store for Sanford J. Zimmerman, chairman and chief executive of Abraham Straus, were heightened last week when it was learned that Federated Department Stores, the Cincinnati-based parent of A., Bloomingdale's, Burdine's, Filene's and other retail department stores, would promote Alan Gilman, A.'s president, to the top job.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 4 (AP)--Arnold Palmer, who was tied for the lead after the first round, faltered slightly today on a windy, cold afternoon, and David Graham and Mac McLendon moved into a tie for the lead after the second round of the $200,000 Florida Citrus open golf tournament.

WHITE PLAINS MICHAEL SURLES had been out of work for more than two years. He was on home relief, drinking a lot and worrying about what to do with his life, when he was assigned last March to a training program for home-relief recipients at Rochambeau High School here.

With the solemnity of a President pressing for passage of an energy bill, Muhammad Ali carried his quest for a rematch with Leon Spinks to the public yesterday.
ATLANTA, March 4 (UPI)--Scientists at the Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center have discovered cystic fibrosis in a young rhesus monkey, opening the way to a better understanding of the disease.

MORE New Jersey homeowners join the ranks of vegetable gardeners each spring. If you plan to savor the taste of some really fresh vegetables this year, and will be starting from scratch, do yourself a favor by keeping your garden plot small this first season.

Contributions to the 67th annual appeal can be sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249.

Of special interest to New Yorkers is one of the items just presented on a 10-year loan/gift from the Chase Manhattan Bank to the Smithsonian Institution. It is a 5-shilling piece that was printed by William Bradford and signed by three of the former mayors of New York: Robert Walter, Johannes DePeyster, and Robert Lurting.

A man who authorities said was the leader of the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang in Manhattan's East Village section was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a woman who had been thrown off the roof of the gang's headquarters last fall, according to the police.

MIDDLETOWN ONE of the biggest and best marathons in the country takes place here and it will be run today at noon. Not as exalted as the Boston Marathon or as widely publicized as the New York City Marathon, the Middletown competition is nonetheless rated among the top of the more than 200 marathons now held every year throughout the United States.

LONDON, March 3 (Reuters)--Violent crime in London increased by 23 percent last year, the police reported today, with juveniles and young people responsible for a major share. In 1935, Orson Welles, then the Wunderkind of the theater, subjected it to his brilliant staging for the Federal Theater and called it "Horse Eats Hat."

ROME, March 9--The founding members of the Red Brigades, a major urban guerrilla organization, went on trial in Turin today after two years of delay and in spite of a systematic campaign of intimidation by terrorists still at large to block the trial.

GUATEMALA, March 9--Four days after Guatemala's presidential elections, the final results had still not been announced today. Rumors spread that the army was preparing to intervene in the dispute between the two main military contenders for power.

Somalia was wise to promise a withdrawal of its troops from the disputed Ogaden region of Ethiopia. It faced not only a military defeat by the Soviet-led Ethiopian and Cuban forces but also continuing international isolation for its aggression, which brought the Communists into Africa as the defenders of recognized frontiers. A retreat will make it possible for African as well as Western nations to press for the removal of most of the outside forces.

WASHINGTON, March 10--In an apparent reversal of statements over the last year, President Carter today endorsed the deregulation of natural gas prices, which is proposed in compromise legislation now being drafted by a HouseSenate conference committee.

Britain is about to undermine President Carter's campaign to curb the spread of nuclear technologies that can be used to make bombs. A British judge has recommended construction of a nuclear fuel reprocessing plant at Windscale, on England's northwest coast. The issue will be referred to Parliament for further debate, but close observers believe final approval of the controversial plant is certain.

The Rev. Hugh Morley, a Capuchin Franciscan priest who served as representative of the International Catholic Union of the Press at the United Nations, died Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital in New York City. He was 69 years old and lived in the city.

WASHINGTON, March 9--President Carter announced today that Somalia had agreed to withdraw its forces from the Ogaden region of Ethiopia where they have been fighting since last July ostensibly in support of an insurrection by ethnic Somalis.

TRENTON, March 9--The New Jersey State Supreme Court unanimously rejected today a suit challenging proposed state regulations on the sale of hearing aids and upheld the right of the Legislature to impose strict consumer-protection laws on business.

WASHINGTON, March 9--The Internal Revenue Service, as expected, proposed regulations today that would virtually destroy the attractiveness of a new type of bank deposit that has proliferated because of the tax evasion opportunity it offers small investors.

KUWAIT, March 9 (AP)--Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia has said that his country would consider recognizing Israel in the event of a comprehensive Middle East peace settlement that provided for an independent Palestinian state.

HOLT, England, March 9 (AP)--Sir Roy Harrod, one of Britain's leading economists and a former economic adviser to the International Monetary Fund, died early today. He was 78 years old. No cause of death was reported.

Doc Watson and Bill Harrell and the Virginians, bluegrass musicians, will pick tunes tomorrow at New York Uni versity's Loeb Student Center Auditorium, 566 La Guardia Place. Shows are at 8 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $5.50 ($4 for N.Y.U. students). Information: 4271488.

NEARLY three years have passed since the inauguration of the wing housing the Robert Lehman Collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the old controversies have cooled even though the issues that generated them have not disappeared. PORTLAND, Ore., March 3--With Tom McCall coming out of retirement to run for a third four-year term as Governor, Oregon voters can expect to be presented with choices that they have faced twice before.

IVOLGINSK, U.S.S.R.--Beneath a large and brightly painted Buddha, the temple was filled with aged faces, eyes dimmed and deepened by long years. YONKERS A talking scallop shell ushers the curious visitors into the 18thcentury drawing room. George Washington glowers at the Brit ish insignia cast in the fireplace. And upstairs Frederick Philipse paces the floor boards with anxiety at his impending imprisonment. These dramatic figures are part of an unusual new puppet program created recently by members of the Philipse Manor staff in Yonkers to teach children American history.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (UPI)--The University of Pennsylvania has announced a tuition increase of $375 for the 1978-79 academic year that begins in September. Spring arrives today at 6:34 P.M., when the sun crosses the equator, making night and day of equal duration in all parts of the earth. SILVERSTONE, England, March 19 (AP)--Keke Rosberg of Finland won the rain-plagued $190,000 International Trophy auto race at Silverstone today in a time of 1:12:49.02. Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil finished less than two seconds behind the winner for second place. Tony Trimmer of England was third and Brett Lunger of Wilmington, Del., fourth in the 117.28-mile race.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19--The Knicks lasted a little longer today than they did last night, but the result was the same--a loss to the Philadelphia 76ers. The 76ers triumphed, 125-118, before a crowd of 17,138 at the Spectrum.

This week Lorillard's True brand becomes the first cigarette to be a New York basic bus advertiser. The concept, introduced eight years ago, allows a single advertiser or product to take over all advertising on a number of buses. Lorillard is taking 100 for two months.

TRENTON, March 28 (AP)--Somerset County College has posted the highest increase in enrollment of any of the state's 18 two-year colleges, education officials say. Figures released yesterday by the State Department of Higher Education showed an 11 percent increase at Somerset during the 1976-77 academic year.

The three main television networks and their local stations--Channels 2, 4 and 7--have scheduled live coverage of President Carter's news conference in Brazil on Thursday at 7 A.M. The following radio stations have scheduled live broadcasts: WCBS-AM, WINS and WMCA.

The recent advance in precious metals prices ran out of steam yesterday. Traders found the 0.6 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index for last month reported yesterday somewhat below expectations. And the one-month postponement of the oil exporters meeting on prices to May, also announced yesterday, removed another possible stimulant.

Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan said yesterday that Mayor Koch appeared to be wavering in his opposition to the Westway, and he urged him to call on Governor Carey not to include money in the state budget for the controversial superhighway.

ALBANY, March 28 (UPI)--The Court of Appeals ruled today that the statemandated wage freeze on New York City agencies during the 1975 fiscal crisis was constitutional, even when it applied to contracts already in effect.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 28--Atlantic City's first gambling casino may open by Memorial Day, but city officials expressed concern today that they might not be ready to provide adequate police protection for visitors or to cope with traffic jams and parking problems.

The New York Court of Appeals unanimously upheld the validity yesterday of three constitutional amendments dealing with the courts, ruling in a one-paragraph decision that they had been properly submitted to voters last November. Their validity had been challenged in a suit, filed by four retired judges.

HOUSTON, March 28--A Federal judge today imposed a one-year prison sentence on a former Houston police officer who was convicted last month of beating a Mexican-American prisoner and then pushing him into a bayou, where he drowned.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 28-- President Carter drew the cheers and enthusiastic applause of thousands of people here today which he concluded a short speech in Spanish with a rousing "Viva Venezuela!"
"It's a time of love and hate," said Ed Westfall, the Islander forward. "Love because it's spring and hate because the playoffs are coming."

WASHINGTON, March 28--Coal miners were at work today in larger numbers than yesterday and with less interference than had been expected from the 10,000 construction workers in the United Mine Workers union who are still technically on strike.
ALBANY, March 28--The popular "I Love New York" television commercials have generated "phenomenal gains" in theater bookings in New York City, according to the State De partment of Commerce.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 28 (AP)--The nation's largest oil company dominated bidding in a $109.6 million lease sale today as the Government offered more than one million acres off the Southeastern coast for oil and gas exploration.

LOS ANGELES, March 28-John Travolta, 24-year-old nominee for an Academy Award as best actor for his performance in "Saturday Night Fever," is forming his own production company and has signed a two-picture agreement with Orion Pictures.

JERUSALEM, March 29--As United Nations peacekeeping troops move slowly and with difficulty into the violent thicket of southern Lebanon, it has become clear that a full Israeli military withdrawal from Lebanese soil is not imminent.

AS "A.E.S. HUDSON ST." is a new weekly series, on ABC Thursdays at 9:30 P.M., it must, I suppose, be examined for any unusual signs of television life. This is another comedy product from the shop of Danny Arnold, the man responsible for "Barney Miller" and "Fish." But whereas "Barney Miller" is set in a...

There's a new outpost of China Seas at Macy's. The textile concern, which is best known for its Indonesian batiks, has taken over a corner of the main-floor Arcade, where scores of wares made from China Seas fabrics are being sold. Colorful umbrellas hang from the ceiling to form a multipatterned, tentlike effect. Sarongs are draped over a long bar so that all the designs can be seen at a glance.

SINCE World War II, very few young jazz musicians whose roots were in prewar jazz have gained prominence. Most of them, faced with a be-bop world, settled into regional, part-time Dixieland groups. Bob Wilber and Dick Wellstood, who appeared in the immediate...

CONCORD, N.H., March 29 (AP)--The Republican National Committee has named Robert Cohen, a former aide to Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr., as the party's fund-raising coordinator for New England. He resigned a year ago as public affairs counsel to Mr. Thomson. Before that, he headed a Manchester advertising agency that went bankrupt.
The United States Open, sponsored by the International Backgammon Association, took place last weekend in New Orleans. The winner in the championship section was Gus...

Like babes in Toyland, three boys from 11 to 14 and a 13-year-old girl went on a buying spree recently in "head shops" around the metropolitan area. They came back with $300 worth of drug-culture paraphernalia that included a "buzz bomb," a "Power Hitter," several "bongs," a baby bottle fitted with both a nipple and a hashish pipe and a felt-tipped pen that allows a surreptitious snort of cocaine in the classroom.

LISTENING to Susan Lang Eddlemon play violin showpieces at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night, one got the impression that this performer, trained at the Juilliard School by Joseph Fuchs, could do just about anything she wanted with her chosen instrument.

HINGHAM, Mass., March 29 (UPI)--A judge today dismissed a suit filed by a Massachusetts hospital that had sought to deny Diane and Gerald Green the right to halt chemotherapy treatments for their 2-year-old son, Chad, who is a leukemia victim.

The long-stalled contract talks between trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road and the Metropolitan Trasportation Authority resumed yesterday as officials in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties announced contingency plans to cope with a possible strike this weekend.
When you witness the transit workers griping in the lunch-hour sunshine out in the Jamaica train repair yards, an issue large as money emerges from their frustration.

President Carter arrived in Brazil and immediately raised the two issues that have exacerbated relations between Washington and Brasilia. During a welcoming ceremony at the airport, Mr. Carter spoke of both human rights and nuclear nonproliferation.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 29--The third Bertrand Russell international tribunal began hearings today on alleged human rights violations in West Germany after its purpose was denounced by both the political leadership and leftist segments.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Close to half the energy in sunlight may be converted to electricity by using a combination of solar cells sensitive to different parts of the solar spectrum, a physicist for the International Business Machines Corporation reported here this week.

Five members of the New York City Board of Estimate who cast 16 of its 22 votes said yesterday that they would vote for an interior landmark designation for Radio City Music Hall despite the objections of its owners.
Jean Gelb, an artist whose work is represented in a number of museum collections, died here on Monday. She was 72 years old.

Major colleges and universities in New York State have granted thousands of degrees through off-campus extension centers that are academically deficient, the State Board of Regents was told yesterday.

New construction in February amounted to $9.7 billion in contract value, 24 percent more than in the same month last year, according to the report yesterday by the F.W. Dodge Division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company.

JUNEAU, Alaska, March 29 (AP)-- Questionnaires that ask unmarried welfare mothers how often they have had sex and with whom have angered some state legislators so much they are vowing to slash funding for the agency that distributes aid for dependent children.

NABLUS, Israeli-Occupied West Bank, March 26--The Palestinians of the West Bank of the Jordan River are feeling less hopeful and more isolated in the aftermath of Israel's invasion of southern Lebanon and the unsuccessful talks last week between President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

Illegal casino-type gambling operations in Queens closed, at least temporarily, last night in the wake of threatened arrests this week by District Attorney John J. Santucci. Policemen inspected 23 buildings in which the so-called "Las Vegas Night" gambling had been conducted but found all shut. Most of the gambling had been in buildings owned by religious groups, but law enforcement officials said that much of the gambling had actually been run by "professionals."

MINNEAPOLIS, March 29 (Reuters)-- Pilots for Northwest Airlines Inc. said today that they planned to strike the airline on April 29 after a mandatory 30-day cooling-off period. The Air Line Pilots Association said that the National Mediation Board had issued permission for the pilots to strike after Northwest rejected the board's offer for binding arbitration.

The dollar was weaker against most European currencies in moderate trading in New York yesterday but gained marginally against the British pound. In The price of gold dropped $2.25 a troy ounce in Zurich to close at $181.375, compared with $183.625 on Tuesday. In London the metal dropped $1.75--from $183 on Tuesday to $181.25 yesterday.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 29 --Straighten out a question mark the right way and it becomes an exclamation point.

Two boys--one 13 years old and the other 14--were arrested last night and charged with shooting to death a 25-year Bronx man early yesterday in return for the promise of a $500 payment.

Contract Deadline: 12:01 A.M., Friday, March 31. Parties: The Daily News, The New York Post, The New York Times, and 10 unions representing 10,000 employees. The bargaining agent for the newspapers is the Publishers Association of New York City.
TO THE HOME SECTION: I read Paul Goldberger's piece on airports [Design Notebook, March 23] as I was trundled in to work on the Hudson Division.

The New York Rangers dispelled the notion last night that their playoff surge was simply a fabrication built on the conquests of mediocre teams. They beat the New York Islanders, 5-1, before a capacity crowd in Madison Square Garden that cheered them with a standing ovation through the game's final 25 seconds.

What accounts for the sluggish productivity and loss of competitiveness in world markets of United States industry? Some key officials of the Carter Administration, including Frank Press, director of the President's Office of Science and Technology Policy, Secretary of Commerce Juanita Kreps and Richard C. Atkinson, head of the National Science Foundation, think the...

TEL AVIV, March 29 (Reuters)--The United States Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. James L. Holloway, arrived in Israel today for a three-day courtesy visit following a similar stay in Egypt. Admiral Holloway is the highest-ranking American officer to visit Israel.

ALTHOUGH the Metropolitan Opera will be winding up its 1977-78 season in little more than two weeks, Puccini's dur able and popular "Tosca" did not enter the current repertory until last night, when the first of six scheduled performances was given.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 (AP)--The United Nations peace force in Lebanon reported its first casualties today. The peacekeeping headquarters in Jerusalem said a Swedish soldier was killed and another injured in a mine explosion near a bridge over the Litani River.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, testifying in a criminal trial yesterday for the first time in his career, defended his handling of a situation almost four years ago that ultimately led to indictments against three of his staff members and a former employee.

BOCA GRANDE, Fla., March 29 (UPI) --A final attempt to free the grounded Mobil oil tanker Eclipse from a sandbar in a narrow channel two miles off Boca Grande failed early today. The Coast Guard and oil company crews awaited the arrival of two oil barges to begin transferring some of the 100,000 barrels of oil from the holds of the 567-foot ship.

WHEN copper, which is normally used for most house wiring, was in short supply during the late 1960's and early 1970's, many house builders switched to aluminum wiring, which cost less and was more readily available.

EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., March 29 (AP)--A pilot who was injured and partly blinded when his F-5E fighter lost its canopy in a simulated air battle was talked through a safe landing by the pilot of another F-5E flying alongside him, the Air Force said today.
REMEMBER when summer furniture was either redwood picnic tables or curlicued wrought iron with flowery cushions? That was before designers...

BRASILIA, March 29--President Carter arrived here this afternoon and before he had left the airport the issues that have strained American-Brazilian relations in recent months were already out in the open.

WASHINGTON, March 29--In a move to head off growing Congressional pressures, President Carter today offered for the first time to pay corn and cotton farmers to let a small part of their land lie idle this spring and to pay wheat farmers a higher subsidy if they do not harvest part of what they have already planted.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29--Relations between the United States and Brazil, which President Carter is visiting today, are in a delicate phase. In fact, the Government has hinted strongly that Mr. Carter is unwelcome.

A sort of delayed Easter parade, postponed by rain from its proper day, took over sunny but breezy midtown Manhattan yesterday. It filled Fifth Avenue with promenading shoppers and turned the Broadway-Times Square area into a crowd scene far beyond the usual Wednesday-matinee pilgrimage.

Improved sales were achieved in February by 32 of the nation's largest retail chains, despite severe weather in a large part of the country, according to a survey by Chain Store Age, a trade publication.

On an upper floor of the New York Hilton, behind a self-imposed news blackout, officials of the New York City Transit Authority and representatives of the Transport Workers Union are trying to work out a new labor contract to replace the one that ends Saturday. Their settlement--with or without a strike--will shape the settlements of all other city labor contracts.
The United States Steel Corporation yesterday announced a price increase of 2.2 percent, or $10.50 a ton, on all its basic steel products, effective April 1.

The greening of New York is late this year--except in the Bronx, a place hardly synonymous with spring in the public mind. There the season is in full bloom at the restored Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden.

SECAUCUS, N.J., March 29--The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission today urged the state to agree to a 150-acre land exchange that is critical to plans by Hartz Mountain Industries to build a 1.6 million-squarefoot shopping center, and a major residential and commercial complex astride the New Jersey Turnpike here.
NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (AP)-- Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 34 points tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 108-103 National Basketball Association victory over New Orleans.
JERUSALEM, March 29--Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel will fly to Cairo tomorrow in an effort to get peace negotiations with Egypt restarted, official sources said today.

BRASILIA, March 29--President Carter arrived here this afternoon and before he had left the airport the issues that have strained American-Brazilian relations in recent months were already out in the open.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Former President Richard M. Nixon agreed today to allow public access to most of the 600,000 documents on his pre-Presidential political career that he had donated to the Government.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 29 (AP)--A Kaysville man has filed a $500,000 damage suit against the Federal Government because he says he was partly paralyzed by a swine flu vaccination. Alden S. Adams filed the suit in Federal District Court and listed 10 unidentified officials of the National Swine Flu Immunization Program as co-defendants.

ROME, March 29--Former Prime Minister Aldo Moro, abducted two weeks ago, appeared today to have directed a veiled appeal to the Italian Government to make an offer of negotiations for his release from his kidnappers.

Elizabeth Keith Oxenaar, a classical harpist and singer who had performed on the CBS radio network under the professional name of Lysbeth Hughes, died Tuesday of cancer at the home of friends, Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Kenney of Owenoke Park, Westport, Conn. She was 66 years old and had been living in Naples, Fla.

ALGIERS, March 29 (Reuters)--At least 15 Mauritanian soldiers were killed when guerrillas of the Polisario Front blew up a train carrying iron ore last weekend, the Algerian news service reported. The guerrillas are fighting for the independence of the former Spanish Sahara territory. Sources in the Mauritanian capital, Nouakchott, said Monday that there had been no casualties in the incident.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 29--An intensive search is under way to find a buyer for the financially troubled Banco Credito y Ahorro Ponceno, one of Puerto Rico's largest banks, which has absorbed heavy losses in recent years.
BRASILIA, March 29 (AP)--Brazilian Air Force jet fighters intercepted and buzzed American airliners carrying part of the White House press corps here yesterday to cover President Carter's visit.

NORTH BRUNSWICK, March 29 (UPI) --New Jersey dentists, trying to attract more business with advertising, joined forces today against proposed state reguations, calling them too stict and liable to drive up the costs of dental care.
Twenty years ago, when a Mies van der Rohe steel table was de rigueur for modern architects, the status symbol for more traditional interior decorators was a Vesey steel table.
Prices of precious metals futures declined along a wide front yesterday, partly in response to weak basic commodity markets and partly in reflection of lower European bullion quotations.
Buddy Mahar an assistant basketball coach at Columbia University, has been selected as the new head coach, it was learned yesterday. His appointment is to be announced at a news conference today.
The New York City Police Department will soon have its first woman chief.

TOKYO, Thursday March 30--The United States dollar plunged yesterday to another postwar low of 221.60 yen, a sharp decline of 4.42 yen from the previous day's closing rate, on the Tokyo foreign exchange market. It was the fifth consecutive day of declines here for the American currency.

LETTUCE is said to be about 95 percent water, which doesn't leave much substance to talk about. Yet 5 percent flavor is enough for those who know lettuce to allow space for it in the garden, even if it is the only crop grown.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 29--"Wanted: a home for twin 10-dayold, motherless foals. Easy to raise. Bottlefed. For information, contact Dr. Fred Adams at the Meadowlands."
Increased institutional buying enabled the stock market to post a modest gain yesterday in accelerated trading.

HAMILTON, Ill., March 29 (UPI)--Five persons, including two children, died today in a fire that engulfed a two-story rural frame home. Four of the victims were identified as Sharon J. White, 26 years old; her son, James D. White, 8; Betty Sue Bettis, 18; and her son, Tommy, 1. The name of the fifth victim was not immediately released.
The Treasury auctioned yesterday oneyear bills at an average yield of 6.877 percent.

YONKERS, March 29--The City Council last night approved a measure to allow the city to order emergency repairs on rental housing and pay for those repairs out of mandatory contributions from landlords.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that the board would investigate whether "bait and switch" techniques had been used by airlines to lure customers with discount fares and then charge them more.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Veterans Administrator Max Cleland says that 80 percent of Vietnam-era veterans "have adjusted well, picked up their lives and moved on" and the V.A. must now focus on the "hard core" who cannot readjust.

Ever since the Carter Administration asked Congress last summer for funds to produce enhanced-radiation nuclear warheads, critics ranging from Soviet propagandists to Western cartoonists have had a field day attacking the so-called "neutron bomb."

PARIS, March 29 (UPI)--Martin Plaa, former professional tennis player and trainer of the Four Musketeers, died today of a heart attack. He was 77 years old. The Four Musketeers--Jean Borotra, Rene LaCoste, Henri Cochet and Jacques Brugnon--dominated world tennis for 10 years beginning in the 1920's. Brugnon died last week.

LONDON, March 29 (AP)--Sir Stewart Duke-Elder, an eye surgeon who treated three monarchs, died on Monday, the Institute of Ophthalmology said today. He was 80 years old. Sir Stewart, who wrote several textbooks on ophthalmology, was eye doctor to Queen Elizabeth II, her father, King George VI, and her uncle, King Edward VIII.
HONG KONK, March 29 (Reuters)--A delegation of the China International Travel Service left Peking today to visit the United States, according to Hsinhua, the official press agency.

MILAN, March 29--It is said that Milanese women are among the most fashionable in the world, and that's probably true. If there exists a new trend in clothes it can be found on the streets of this large, industrial city in northern Italy.

The Shubert Organization, the world's largest legitimate theater chain, announced yesterday that, starting in April 1979, it will set up a national computerized ticket-selling system giving each customer access to every seat in a Shubert house.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Arnold R. Miller, the embattled president of the United Mine Workers, suffered what was described as "a mild stroke" today, losing the feeling in his left side, and was hospitalized, a union officer said.
With three members of the Cosmos providing strength, a selection of American players 20 years of age and under won an eight-nation tournament in Switzerland Tuesday by shutting out every opponent.

The Federal Government is preparing to strengthen and expand the $2.7 billion cornerstone of its school aid program, Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, which provides supplementary instructional support for six million disadvantaged students.

New York City's six biggest banks cut back their loans to the city after the Federal Government began its loan program, Senator William Proxmire said yesterday, adding that the banks' own figures proved this.

LAST WEEK I saw "Saturday Night Fever." Having grown up in a working-class neighborhood in the Bronx, I took my place in the darkened theater expectantly. No matter what, I was going to have a good time at this movie. And I did, but in a way and for a reason I could never have foreseen.

MOSCOW, March 29 (UPI)--Members of a delegation traveling with the House Armed Services Committee met today with 10 Jewish women and promised to help one of them seeking medical care for her infant daughter in the United States.
JERUSALEM, March 29--Israel has begun producing oil offshore in the Gulf of Suez south of the occupied Sinai town of El Tur. Two wells began operation on Sunday and a third is nearing completion.
CONCORD, N.H., March 28--The thing about the New Hampshire flag flap is that the mockery of outsiders was not echoed here. No one here laughs at Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. anymore.
Len S. Pinover, founder, former chairman and chief executive officer of Intaglio Service Corporation, died yesterday in Jupiter, Fla., after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 29--Dick Battista is not only the only professional athlete with a heart transplant, but he also is the only one of the 144 bowlers in the $70,000 Long Island open with a cracked rib.

Three troubled National Hockey League franchises have communicated with the New Jersey Sports and Exposition. Authority about transferring their teams to the Meadowlands complex in East Rutherford, N.J., an N.H.L. general manager said yesterday.

RENO, Nev., March 29 (UPI)--Jack Nicklaus, this year's leading money winner on the PGA Tour, was installed today as a 7-2 favorite in next week's Masters tournament by the Plantation Casino oddsmakers. Hale Irwin and Hubert Green were listed at 6-1, Tom Watson 8-1, Tom Weiskopf 10-1 and Ben Crenshaw and Gary Player 12-1.
The credit markets ended their weeklong slide yesterday afternoon as bond prices recovered in response to the Federal Reserve's decision to buy Treasury notes and bonds.

HACKENSACK, March 29--With the hospital's chief anesthesiologist on the stand reading from patients' charts, the prosecution asserted today that Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich was at the bedsides of two patients on the days they suddenly died in 1966 at Riverdell Hospital after recovering normally from surgery.

Danny Meehan, who was nominated for a Tony Award for his performance as the hoofer who befriended Barbra Streisand in the Broadway musical "Funny Girl" in 1964, died yesterday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital after a threemonth illness. He was 47 years old.

The nation's leading college scorer, Freeman Williams of Portland State, was not in the lineup, but that took nothing away from the talented display of basketball at St. John's Alumni Hall in Queens last night.

A state court judge in Utah ruled yesterday that the Curtiss-Wright Corporation would not be held in contempt of court for failing to heed an earlier court order that the company halt plans to wage a proxy fight.

Long Island's Waterfowl Festival, held in conjunction with the 55th annual United States National Decoy Show and bird carving exhibit, will be held at the hall of Local 25 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Union in Melville this weekend.

The Long Island Lighting Company increased its quarterly dividend on common stock to 42 cents a share from 40 cents a share at the monthly meeting of the board of directors yesterday. The new quarterly rate is equivalent to an annual rate of $1.70 a share, a rise of 7 cents. With the exception of 1974, the dividend has been increased each year since 1958.

The proposed federally aided renewal of the devastated South Bronx would cost more than $1 billion, take in the whole borough south of Fordham Road and be coordinated by the Mayor's office--not by an independent authority as some Federal officials have suggested--the Koch administration has decided.

A disagreement among the six offtrack betting regional organizations in New York's State has temporarily shelved legislative plans to reduce the parimutuel takeout at New York Racing Association tracks.

"Some progress" in New York City's newspaper labor negotiations was reported yesterday by Douglas La Chance, president of the deliverers' union. But he asserted last night that a strike by his union at The Daily News at a midnight deadline tonight was "an extreme likelihood" because of proposals that he called "retrogressions."

SAN FRANCISCO--A husband-and-wife scientific team has built a miniature treatfent plant for public sewage in their backyard, and produced some new answers to the problem of preserving the nation's rapidly dwindling coastal marshlands and estuaries.
BOSTON, March 29 (UPI)--A 290-foot Cypriot freighter left United States territorial waters today on her way to Cuba carrying a potentially lethal cargo of 115 one-ton cylinders of liquid chlorine.

Webster, the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he was dissatisfied because the number of blacks and members of other minority groups in the bureau was so small and that he had ordered accelerated recruitment and training of special agents from among these groups.

The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that in its appeals of verdicts against it in a Federal antitrust suit brought by Berkey Photo Inc. it was dropping the law firm that had been handling the case.

CAIRO, March 29--The Arab League wound up its council meeting today by formally condemning the "aggressive" intervention of the Soviet Union and Cuba in the Horn of Africa and calling for their forces to withdraw immediately.

The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

MIAMI, March 29--Muhammad Ali looked all washed up on the tube. To be sure, he didn't appear on the tube and he wasn't lurking behind the slot machines when Larry Holmes did a job on Earnie Shavers in Las Vegas the other day. Just the same, the performance served to indict Ali as a fighter, in absentia.

Despite Mayor Koch's continued insistence that the city cannot afford raises for its employees, both the city and the municipal labor unions now agree that there will be enough savings in next year's budget to finance some increases for the 200,000 city workers.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 29 (AP)-- Brian McBride, the leader of an antismoking group, brought assault charges against Caligera Filipazzo, alleging that the man had blown smoke into his face on a bus. Mr. Filipazzo admitted smoking but denied blowing the smoke in Mr. McBride's face.
The United States Steel Corporation yesterday announced a price increase of 2.2 percent, or $10.50 a ton, on all its basic steel products, effective April 1.
General Mills Inc. reported yesterday a 6.7 percent gain in profits for the quarter and an 18.9 percent increase for the nine months ended Feb. 26.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 29 (AP)--J. Hardin Peterson Sr., a United States Representative for 18 years, died yesterday in Lakeland General Hospital. He was 84 years old and had been ill since October.
UNION SPRINGS, Ala.--Horse trailers filled the parking area and bird dogs yelped and danced in their kennels on the opening day of the Dixie open puppy classic at Sedgefields Hunting Preserve.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29--A highranking official in the Palestine Liberation Organization said in an interview today that the guerrillas would hold their fire in some parts of southern Lebanon to avoid providing "a pretext to perpetuate Israeli occupation."
MILAN, Italy, March 29-- Sometimes the manuequins selling next winter's clothes here join up in groups of six or 10 and stomp down the runway in ca dence in their heavy boots.

It was a month in search of identity. January and February, though not attractive, had their own unrelenting character. March produced a big snowstorm, the kind that usually lands winter's last knockout punch.

OCALA, Fla., March 31--The legal fight over how far the nation can pursue school desegregation has settled on an unlikely battleground.

The Atlantic Electric Company yesterday requested a $35.7 million rate increase that could cost the average homeowner at least $4.50 a month.

Huge losses incurred by the International Basic Economy Corporation have prompted the divestment of unprofitable and marginal businesses, the latest of which was its Bellows International division sold two months ago. In its report yesterday for the fourth quarter and year 1977, IBEC attributed a major share of the deficit to this division and to housing operation losses.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)--Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, asked a Senate Committee today to investigate reports concerning the United States Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, John C. West.
MOSCOW, March 31--The Soviet Union was reported today to have agreed to an American proposal to begin talks to ban hunter-killer satellites in space.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)--Major conservation organizations, which once praised President Carter, are now charging the Administration with bowing to political pressure and failing to reform the "pork barrel" system of water project construction.

Phyllis Lamhut is a sassy dancer who always appears to be urging audiences: "Hey, look at this. I want to show you something kooky."

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 31--President Carter arrived here late tonight to begin a three-day visit, the first state visit by an American President to any subSaharan African nation.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 31--Federal authorities took over the ailing Banco Credito y Ahorro Ponceno today and promptly sold it at auction for $36.1 million to the island's largest bank and a major bank of Spain.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 31--Three special schools with racial quotas will be established here to help ease racial imbalances in the state's largest city, whose population is 76 percent white and whose public-school enrollment is almost 70 percent members of minority groups, the City Board of Education announced today.
The stock market, troubled by the report of a record trade deficit in February, declined slightly yesterday in the last trading session of the first quarter.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 30--President Suharto, unanimously re-elected to a third five-year term last week, installed a new Cabinet Wednesday, apparently ending the political crisis that has gripped Southeast Asia's largest nation for several months.
TOKYO, March 31--The Japanese Government decided today to try to open the controversial New Tokyo International Airport in the latter half of May.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)--Automobiles, trucks and buses traveled an estimated 1,466 billion miles in the United States in 1977, the Federal Highway Administration reported today. That is equal to about 3 millon round trips to the moon, and it is 4 percent more than the estimate of 1,409 billion miles in 1976. The figures are based on data compiled by each state highway agency.

Directors of the New York Stock Exchange approved in principle yesterday a rule that would establish a new category of member--the registered competitive market-maker. The rule must be submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval.

WASHINGTON, April 6--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States had assurances that Turkey would reopen American military bases if the arms embargo was lifted and that Turkish Cypriots would make significant proposals for resolving the Cyprus dispute in the next 10 days.

MUNICH, West Germany, April 6 (Reuters)--Helmut Langfelder, head of West Germany's largest aerospace company, Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm, was killed today in a helicopter crash in southern France, a company spokesman announced here.

Fifteen years ago, cigarette bootlegging was strictly for amateurs. Vacationers on their way home from Florida saved a few dollars by stocking up in states like North Carolina with low cigarette taxes. But then came enormous increases in cigarette taxes in places like New York, pushing the price differential to as much as 21 cents a pack. Professional bootleggers now shuttle back and forth between the low-tax and high-tax states.

WASHINGTON, April 6--The Carter Administration today increased its estimate of the damage the economy could suffer from the new farm bill now before Congress.

AMHERST, Mass., April 6(AP)--About 75 University of Massachusetts protesters voted early today to accept a series of housing policy compromises and ended their 17-hour occupation of the university's administration building. Student leaders said the key compromise reached was a measure aimed at guaranteeing students a lease arrangement for university housing.

NORTH PERKY, Ohio, April 6 (UPI)-- An explosion injured seven men today at the construction site of a nuclear power plant in northeastern Ohio.
